description: Outstanding repairs and rising waters could lead to collapse of Iraq's Mosul Dam - the country's biggest - killing hundreds of thousands
title: Mosul Dam could collapse a year after Iraqi forces reclaimed it from ISIS
title_page: Mosul Dam could collapse a year after Iraqi forces reclaimed it from ISIS | Daily Mail Online
text:
US president Obama stressed need to make emergency repairs to Iraqi PM
US State Department officials have warned that up to 500,000 people could be killed and more than a million left homeless should Iraq's Mosul Dam - the country's biggest - collapse due to insufficient maintenance.
Rising water levels in spring, when the Tigris is swollen by rain and melting snow, could lead to the breach of the 3.6-km (2.2-mile) long Mosul dam, which was retaken from the Islamic State by Iraqi and Kurdish forces more than 16 months ago.
The New York Times reported that the death toll and damage could be contained if Iraqi citizens received adequate warning or the dam collapsed only partially.
General view of the Mosul dam on the Tigris River, around 50km north of Mosul, northern Iraq. Rising water levels in spring could lead to the breach of the 3.6-km (2.2-mile) long structure
Kurdish fighters stood guard at Mosul Dam in Iraq in August 2015 after they and Iraqi forces retook the dam from the Islamic State
There is also the possibility that the dam is breached in the summer or fall, when the water level is lower.
In a call to Iraq's prime minister Haider al-Abadi, US president Barack Obama highlighted the need to make emergency repairs to avoid the tragedy.
Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, also stressed the importance of carrying out maintenance works at the dam during a meeting with Abadi in Baghdad.
American officials called on the Iraqi government to start warning its citizens about the perils of a possible breach in the dam, and where to find safety should the dam collapse.
Built in 1984 by a German and Italian consortium and located 30 miles upstream from Mosul, Iraq's biggest dam has long been a maintenance nightmare, with serious structural flaws.
Some 600 Iraqis worked at the site, relentlessly drilling holes in the gypsum base under the structure and filling them with a cement grout mixture.
The operation, which was carried out three times a day, six days a week, was a desperate attempt to prevent water from eroding the dam's base.
ISIS fighters took over the dam in August 2014 raising fears that they might blow it up and unleash a wall of water on Mosul and Baghdad that could kill thousands of civilians.
In a joint Kurdish and Iraqi effort, the dam was wrestled back at the end of the month.
But many of the Iraqi workers did not return to the site and the Iraqi government failed to resume regular maintenance.
The Obama administration installed 92 instruments to measure the pressure on the dam and the sediment in the water nearby to assess the rate at which the gypsum base was disintegrating.
Prime Minister Matteo Renzi said in December that the country would deploy 450 troops near the site to protect workers carrying out repairs
ISIS fighters took over the dam in August 2014 raising fears that they might blow it up and unleash a wall of water on Mosul and Baghdad that could kill thousands of civilians. The site was wrestled back at the end of the month by a joint Iraqi-Kurdish operation
But it stopped short from undertaking the costly repair project itself, urging instead the World Bank to agree that that $200 million of a $1.2 billion loan for Iraq would be for Mosul Dam repairs.
Italy also stepped up efforts to protect the dam. An Italian company, the Trevi Group, has been negotiating with the Iraqi government to make emergency repairs at an estimated cost of more than $380million, according to Iraqi officials. Trevi said work will start almost immediately to 'safeguard the stability' of a dam that 'is seriously damaged,'
'The presence of the Italian contingent alongside the Iraqi army and international forces is fundamentally important for the security of the project,' the statement said.
Prime Minister Matteo Renzi said in December that the country would deploy 450 troops near the site to protect workers carrying out repairs.
Renzi said the dam project was a concrete way to safeguard civilians and oppose Islamist militants. Italy has not joined France and US in air strikes on ISIS in Syria.
'Everybody was saying 'let's bomb here', 'let's bomb there', 'bomb, bomb'. I said, 'Let's do something useful',' Renzi said in an interview with Italian radio.
The dam must be repaired because it could cause a civilian disaster,' Renzi said. 'We will fix the dam and the workers will be defended by our troops, who are already present in Iraq.'
However, plans to send Italian troops have stalled after the head of Iraq's ministry of water resources Moshin al-Shammari, also a supporter of the anti-American Shia cleric Moktada al-Sadr, said that Iraq did not need any 'foreign support' in guarding the dam
'There is no need for Italian forces to protect the dam,' Mahdi Rasheed, an adviser to Mr. Shammari, said Sunday in a telephone interview.
